snippet.textDisplay:
Seriously. Why are we making videos like this? This topic was a nightmare. How do you talk about a continent as diverse as Africa, to explain larger trends? Not only is there a wide variety of sources, experts disagree with each other on what they can predict about the future. So the time we took to rewrite this script over and over was insane.


Still, there is no chance this video won’t make people angry, on all sides of this issue. Some may not agree with the conclusions we have come to. Some will think there are other aspects we could and should have mentioned. Or lament that we generalized too much.


But we had to generalize or this video would just have become a hour-long documentary. And we think the topic is too important to not discuss it.


So we read a lot and talked too many experts with very different opinions and interpretations. Also we tried to prepare our sources in a way that walks you through our thought process and helps you to make up your own mind.


This video was sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of a Grant. They did not take part in the production of the video though.


Sources and comments: https://sites.google.com/view/sourcesoverpopulationandafrica
snippet.textOriginal:
Seriously. Why are we making videos like this? This topic was a nightmare. How do you talk about a continent as diverse as Africa, to explain larger trends? Not only is there a wide variety of sources, experts disagree with each other on what they can predict about the future. So the time we took to rewrite this script over and over was insane. 


Still, there is no chance this video won’t make people angry, on all sides of this issue. Some may not agree with the conclusions we have come to. Some will think there are other aspects we could and should have mentioned. Or lament that we generalized too much. 


But we had to generalize or this video would just have become a hour-long documentary. And we think the topic is too important to not discuss it.


So we read a lot and talked too many experts with very different opinions and interpretations. Also we tried to prepare our sources in a way that walks you through our thought process and helps you to make up your own mind.


This video was sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of a Grant. They did not take part in the production of the video though. 


Sources and comments: https://sites.google.com/view/sourcesoverpopulationandafrica

snippet.textDisplay: Africa has enough land and resources to feed and accommodate its people. The problem is European countries stealing and pilfering their resources. Look at what oil companies have done to their rivers and forests. They’ve damaged the land by mining and using chemicals in the soil that affects the foods Africans are used to eating. Africa’s problem is not one of over population but one brought on by European and other nations like China. The people are not getting anything from their oil, gas, diamonds, gold and numerous other minerals etc. if they don’t find a way to stop these countries from stealing their natural resources they won’t and can’t survive. How is it possible Africa is the richest continent in the world with the poorest people?

"Ok guys so we did not really get a straight answer from our 'scientists', so anything we say here can be objectively not correct."

Thats the most terrible bullet proof argument of all times. If you don't have atleast a theory funded by an university, don't post it. Most of your sources came from UN which is basically futile. I could say that the reason why there are much less men in Russia is because parents "prefer" women children. All you did in this video was getting data about Africa (almost a hole freaking continent) and simply make a hypothesis.

There are dozens of countries in Africa and each one have their own culture about children and contraceptives, you cannot just swallow your "3 meta perfect solution" into their society. Some other countries are even more screwed that I doubt their corrupt government can make these programs, making your solution obsolete.

Yet you continue your same bullshittery, when you are not getting biased sources, you are making them up. Good job, you guys aren't doing a favor for science. I suggest you to keep making universe/physics videos because they are atleast comproved to be true. Don't lose your time with sociology when you cannot even get proper sources.

snippet.textDisplay:
Man... you guys are so damn socialist, but you have no idea of your own bias.
Freedom is the only difference between good and bad countries. But you didn’t say a single thing about that only factor in your moving-pieces-around-a-chessboard “synopsis”.


Freedom is such an important factor that it even defeats any racist argument about genetics and IQ: China vs Hong Kong, N. Korea vs S. Korea, S. Africa vs everywhere else in Africa.

But you guys seem to think like the elites: people are just pieces on a chessboard to be moved around. Or maybe they’re like animals: give them healthcare, food, and other presents and they’ll do what you want.

People will never be like that.

snippet.textDisplay:
Subsaharan Africa is not a "made up idea". It's a politically correct term for talking about "Black Africa", that is the parts of Africa that have been inhabited by black people since time immemorial, juxtaposed against North Africa which has been inhabited by lighter skinned peoples such as the Berbers, Arabs, Copts, and so forth. Civil wars, government corruption, and the like don't explain the entirety of their situation. The same divergent evolution in humans that produced a variety of skin tones, eye shapes, hair textures, disease resistances, bone density, etc. also produced differences in the brain. There are bound to be differences in temperament, time preference, and intelligence. Intelligence can be viewed as "general intelligence" or divided into multiple categories such as mathematical, linguistic, kinesthetic, etc. Regardless of the number of categories there are going to be differences between the average mental attributes of any two populations.


Colonialism actually increased Africa's material wealth, not that I think material wealth is a good argument for colonialism. There is an innate desire in all peoples to have things their way, to make their own destiny without a bunch of outsider busy-bodies telling them how to run their own affairs. An individual, and oftentimes even entire groups of people can decide that trading self-ownership for subservience, and some material gain is not worth it. Fortunately for the Subsaharan Africans, their lower average intelligence is not just a curse. In some cases it can be a boon. This will make it harder to sell them on antinatalism and other destructive "big-brained" ideas that have taken hold in other parts of the world. High intelligence might grant a greater capacity for logic, but this also gives a greater capacity for bending one's thinking into mind-pretzels so as to justify bad ideas.
snippet.textOriginal:
Subsaharan Africa is not a "made up idea". It's a politically correct term for talking about "Black Africa", that is the parts of Africa that have been inhabited by black people since time immemorial, juxtaposed against North Africa which has been inhabited by lighter skinned peoples such as the Berbers, Arabs, Copts, and so forth. Civil wars, government corruption, and the like don't explain the entirety of their situation. The same divergent evolution in humans that produced a variety of skin tones, eye shapes, hair textures, disease resistances, bone density, etc. also produced differences in the brain. There are bound to be differences in temperament, time preference, and intelligence. Intelligence can be viewed as "general intelligence" or divided into multiple categories such as mathematical, linguistic, kinesthetic, etc. Regardless of the number of categories there are going to be differences between the average mental attributes of any two populations.


Colonialism actually increased Africa's material wealth, not that I think material wealth is a good argument for colonialism. There is an innate desire in all peoples to have things their way, to make their own destiny without a bunch of outsider busy-bodies telling them how to run their own affairs. An individual, and oftentimes even entire groups of people can decide that trading self-ownership for subservience, and some material gain is not worth it. Fortunately for the Subsaharan Africans, their lower average intelligence is not just a curse. In some cases it can be a boon. This will make it harder to sell them on antinatalism and other destructive "big-brained" ideas that have taken hold in other parts of the world. High intelligence might grant a greater capacity for logic, but this also gives a greater capacity for bending one's thinking into mind-pretzels so as to justify bad ideas.

snippet.textDisplay:
How much fertility matters to poverty?
India mostly extremely poor. Over 1 billion people
China mostly poor, over 1 billion people.


People have more kids in poor countries because the struggle to survive is indifferent whether you have 1 kid or 4 kids.
You Have to make a plan. You have to find a way to get food and water. So more mouths to feed now for 16-18 years benefits you more for the next 50-60 years. Because your kids can support the family. And government subsidies for poor families are a thing. It could be as high as $200-$300 per kid that a gov pays you.


1 kid can cost $200 to feed but 2 kids will only cost $300-$400. Meaning you gain that tiny bit extra to be able to slowly start living above starvation levels and be able to start affording stuff like clothes, shoes or a $50 phone for business.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly from observing my country, one of the many reasons why people have many children is because of the low economy and access to resources. Because of this it's more of trying to survive than anything else. And some people think having more kids means having more opportunities or people to care for you and work for you in the future, and having more kids means more could survive later on.

It's like having access to so many universities and being accepted to a few. Only the ones that take you in would give you a chance for the future.


If people had access to more resources to live a better life, like mentioned in the video, having kids would be a decision rather than a necessity to survival.

snippet.textDisplay:
How about for a video topic: scientific pros and cons of committing suicide. Nothing spiritual or romantic, like "it's selfish" or "because it'll get better" or "you'll hurt the people you love for the rest of their lives" (who'll probably forget you as they age and then they, too, will die someday anyway) or "you have so much to live for that won't matter in an indifferent universe that will end someday, anyway".

So far, my arguments for suicide is that I'll be one less body to use resources on, I don't have to spend my days physically and mentally sick, and, depending on if my family actually follows my burial wishes, I'll feed the Earth with my nutrients; plus, I'll be one less contributor to carbon emissions and pollution.

And so far, I haven't thought of an argument against suicide.
snippet.textOriginal:

Nothing spiritual or romantic, like "it's selfish" or "because it'll get better" or "you'll hurt the people you love for the rest of their lives" (who'll probably forget you as they age and then they, too, will die someday anyway) or "you have so much to live for that won't matter in an indifferent universe that will end someday, anyway".

So far, my arguments for suicide is that I'll be one less body to use resources on, I don't have to spend my days physically and mentally sick, and, depending on if my family actually follows my burial wishes, I'll feed the Earth with my nutrients; plus, I'll be one less contributor to carbon emissions and pollution.
